title: William Paul (attorney)
text:
William Lewis Paul (May 7, 1885 – March 4, 1977) was an American attorney, legislator, and political activist from the <a href="Tlingit%20people">Tlingit</a> nation of Southeast <a href="Alaska">Alaska</a>. He was known as a leader in the <a href="Alaska%20Native%20Brotherhood">Alaska Native Brotherhood</a>.
Early life.
William Lewis Paul was born in <a href="Tongass%20Island">Tongass Village</a> in <a href="Southeast%20Alaska">Southeast Alaska</a>, the second child of Louis Francis Paul (a.k.a. Pyreau) and <a href="Tillie%20Paul">Tillie Paul</a>, a Tlingit couple with Scots and French ancestry as well. William's Tlingit name was "Shgúndi" (or "Shgwíndi" in the southern Tlingit dialects) and he was a member of the Raven moiety in the "Teeyhittaan" clan. Tillie Paul was a teacher with <a href="Sheldon%20Jackson">Sheldon Jackson</a>'s <a href="Presbyterianism">Presbyterian</a> mission among the Tlingit, later <a href="Sheldon%20Jackson%20College">Sheldon Jackson College</a>. William and his brothers all also attended the <a href="Carlisle%20Indian%20Industrial%20School">Carlisle Indian Industrial School</a> in <a href="Carlisle%2C%20Pennsylvania">Carlisle, Pennsylvania</a>.
Activism and career.
William and his brother, Louis Paul (1887–1956), are considered foundational members of the Alaska Native Brotherhood (ANB). In the 1920s, they extended its presence to every Native village in Southeast Alaska. The organization pressed for voting rights, desegregation, and social services, as well as advancing the first Tlingit and <a href="Haida%20people">Haida</a> land claims in Alaska. William Paul served several times as the ANB's Grand President and Grand Secretary.
William Paul was the first Alaska Native to become an attorney, the first to be elected to Alaska Territorial House of Representatives, and the first to serve as an officer in the federal <a href="Bureau%20of%20Indian%20Affairs">Bureau of Indian Affairs</a>. He helped draft the legislation to adopt Alaska's flag in 1927. He played a major role in the <a href="Alaska%20Native%20Claims%20Settlement%20Act">Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act</a> (ANCSA) of 1971.
His first run for the House in 1922/1923 was challenged legally and became an ultimately successful test case on citizenship rights of Indians to vote and hold office. Paul was defeated in his third run for the seat, in 1928, partly because of accusations that he had received payments from the salmon canning industry that he had vilified repeatedly in print.
He ran unsuccessfully for the office of territorial attorney general in 1932.
In the 1950s Paul brought an important land claims test case, "<a href="Tee-Hit-Ton%20Indians%20v.%20United%20States">Tee-Hit-Ton vs. U.S.</a>", on behalf of his own Tlingit clan, which was unsuccessful but which laid the groundwork for the later ANCSA.
Death.
William Paul died in <a href="Seattle%2C%20Washington">Seattle, Washington</a>, on March 4, 1977.
